items.title: How can i have a control over Server Streaming?
items.body:
Hi, 
I have a scenario which is described with the following:
gRPC Version is : 1.19.0
i am streaming data from server to client by using API IServerStreamWriter. 
On the Client side i am trying to read the streamed data by using IAsyncStreamReader :

while (await call.ResponseStream.MoveNext().ConfigureAwait(false))
 {
      ......
 }

Since there are no data streamed from client side, i found that i am not getting out of this loop (client side) as fast as i expected.

**First Question**      : Do i need to set the completeness of the streaming from the server side.
**Second Question** : Am i able (On the client side) to check that the streaming (ResponseStream) is Completed?     
otherwise this Call **call.ResponseStream.MoveNext()** causes some exception, because this call tries to pick up unavailable data.

**Third Question**   : Is there any possibilities to define some time out for waiting the data on the client side.

I have so far checked what is provided by the API on the server side IServerStreamWriter, and on the client side IAsyncStreamReader, which it doesn't help me to achieve my Goal.
Do i need to get a new upgraded gRPC version, which could help me further?

Thanks a lot for any help.

Best regards
Anas

items.title: xdsResolver run() in a loop, consume a lot of CPU
items.body:
### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?
go language, v1.31.0

### What operating system (Linux, Windows,...) and version?
MacOS version 10.14.6

### What runtime / compiler are you using (e.g. python version or version of gcc)
N/A

### What did you do?
I am running a simple XDS client.  GetMyAddress in the below is part of HTTP handler, the code snippet as in the following
 
```
import (
  "context"
  "flag"
  "fmt"
  "log"
  "net/http"
  "time"

  "github.com/gin-gonic/gin"
  _ "golang.org/x/net/context"
  "google.golang.org/grpc"
  _ "google.golang.org/grpc/xds"
)
var (
  conn *grpc.ClientConn
)

type Env struct {
  xds_address string
}

type ErrorResponse struct {
  Status string `json:status`
  Error  string `json.error`
}

func (env Env) GetMyAddress(c *gin.Context) {
  conn, err := grpc.Dial(env.xds_address, grpc.WithInsecure(),grpc.WithBlock())
  if err != nil {
    rsp := ErrorResponse{"failed", err.Error()}
    c.JSON(http.StatusInternalServerError, rsp)
    return
  }
  defer conn.Close()
  c.JSON(http.StatusOK, {})
}

func main() {
  address := flag.String("host", "xds:///testing", "load balancer URL")
  var port = flag.Int("port", 9080, "TCP/IP port for listening to")
  flag.Parse()
  env := Env{xds_address: *address}
  router := gin.Default()
  router.GET("/srs", env.GetMyAddress)
  router.Run(fmt.Sprintf(":%v", *port))
}
```

### What did you expect to see?
I don't expect the CPU usage too high

### What did you see instead?
I see one of go routine running in a loop,

My project uses MySQL connector, which use OpenSSL as its dependency.
I've integrate gRPC with my project using `FetchContent` described [here](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/tree/master/src/cpp), and I also have OpenSSL installed in my system. What I tried was:

- Installing OpenSSL with Homebrew, then link manually to system path on macOS. 
- Installing OpenSSL with vcpkg on Windows.

They both doesn't work.

Also there are some issues discussing about similar problem in #23113.

items.title: Using gRPC in C++ is horrendous prove me wrong
items.body:
Prove me wrong but gRPC dependency in C++ application is the worst thing that you could possibly do. It has insane amounts of transitive dependencies and it takes forever to build. We tried to integrate it into a game. `vcpkg install grpc` took about 17 minutes on my friend's PC. While the entire game client builds in <1 minute.

gRPC in C++ is a bloated monster and you should think twice before using it.

Problems appear with release 1.31.1.
New gem can be installed in arch x86_64 though

items.title: ClientWriter::Write() does not return false when stream is closed by the server
items.body:
<!--
PLEASE DO NOT POST A QUESTION HERE.
This form is for bug reports and feature requests ONLY!

For general questions and troubleshooting, please ask/look for answers at StackOverflow, with "grpc" tag: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/grpc

For questions that specifically need to be answered by gRPC team members, please ask/look for answers at grpc.io mailing list: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/grpc-io

Issues specific to *grpc-java*, *grpc-go*, *grpc-node*, *grpc-dart*, *grpc-web* should be created in the repository they belong to (e.g. https://github.com/grpc/grpc-LANGUAGE/issues/new)
-->

### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?
gRPC v1.16 with C++

### What operating system (Linux, Windows,...) and version?
Debian testing

### What runtime / compiler are you using (e.g. python version or version of gcc)
GCC 8.3.0

### What did you do?
Taking the `RecordRoute()` call defined in [examples/protos](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/examples/protos/route_guide.proto) as:
```javascript
rpc RecordRoute(stream Point) returns (RouteSummary) {}
```
I [modified the server implementation](https://github.com/santigl/grpc/blob/461fc70faea60af17c708e918d8fd47c42489a4f/examples/cpp/route_guide/route_guide_server.cc#L106) to immediately return `Status::OK` without reading messages from the client's stream. 

### What did you expect to see?
`ClientWriter::Write()` returning `false`when the client calls it for the second time.

### What did you see instead?
`ClientWriter::Write()` keeps returning `true`, failing to indicate to the client that the server has closed its end of the RPC.

#### CLI outputs
These are the outputs obtained when running the adaptation of the `route_guide` example to recreate this issue from this branch: https://github.com/santigl/grpc/tree/santigl/server-close-client-stream/examples/cpp/route_guide. (The code can be built and run using the same instructions provided in the gRPC docs.)

##### Server
```bash
> ./route_guide_server
DB parsed, loaded 100 features.
Server listening on 0.0.0.0:50051
RecordRoute() called, immediately returning OK
```

##### Client
```bash
> ./route_guide_client    
DB parsed, loaded 100 features.
-------------- RecordRoute --------------
Visiting point 41.5302, -74.8416 writer->Write()
Visiting point 40.2647, -74.7072 writer->Write()
Visiting point 40.1809, -74.4158 writer->Write()
Visiting point 40.4318, -74.0836 writer->Write()
Visiting point 40.6422, -74.7728 writer->Write()
Visiting point 40.7114, -74.9746 writer->Write()
Visiting point 40.4701, -74.4782 writer->Write()
Visiting point 40.1809, -74.4158 writer->Write()
Visiting point 41.0322, -74.7872 writer->Write()
Visiting point 41.6561, -74.6722 writer->Write()
Called writer->Write() 10 times
writer->Finish() returned OK

```

### Related issue
This is the same behavior as described in #14812 for the async implementation.

items.title: Incorrect warnings when multiple paths are specified in `ProtoRoot` attribute
items.body:
### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?

gRPC-dotnet v2.31.0
C#

### What operating system (Linux, Windows,...) and version?

macOS 10.15

### What runtime / compiler are you using (e.g. python version or version of gcc)

dotnet core v3.1

### What did you do?

Compile gRPC contracts with multiple paths specified in `ProtoRoot` attribute, in order to import specific proto files from `googleapis` repository without manually copying them.

Updated info that might help:

Below is my contract folder structure that works:

    contracts/
        <my-service>/
            ... // proto files
        googleapis/
            ... // proto files

in the `.csproj` file:

    <Protobuf Include="contracts/<my-service>/*.proto" ProtoRoot="contracts/<my-service>; contracts/googleapis" ... />

### What did you expect to see?

No warning should show up given the paths in `Include` and `ProtoRoot` attributes are correct.

### What did you see instead?

`/Users/<user>/.nuget/packages/grpc.tools/2.31.0/build/_protobuf/Google.Protobuf.Tools.targets(167,5): warning : Protobuf item 'contracts/<my-service>/<proto-file>.proto' has the ProtoRoot metadata 'contracts/<my-service>;contracts/googleapis' which is not prefix to its path. Cannot compute relative path.`

### Anything else we should know about your project / environment?

This was introduced by commit 5494c54cee7ef72b21cb68014cb6acba3facd3e6 in #22869 , which added a validation against `ProtoRoot` and `Include` path attributes. Yet scenarios where multiple paths are specified correctly in `ProtoRoot` also lead to warnings. Warnings should not show up in those cases.

items.title: Authenticate TLS client channel
items.body:
### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?
1.29.1

### What operating system (Linux, Windows,...) and version?
Windows

### What runtime / compiler are you using (e.g. python version or version of gcc)
MSVC 

### What did you do?
I am trying to validate the client TLS certificate during the channel connection not on every request.  This can be done in the rpc itself using the auth_context or by using an AuthMetadataProcessor.  Both of these options require that the client certificate is validated on each request.

By using the grpc_impl::experimental::TlsCredentialsOptions and specifying the server_authorization_check_config the client can easily validate the server.  How does the server perform similar operation to validate the client only during channel connection not on every request. 


### What did you see instead?
When setting the server_authorization_check_config on the TlsCredentialsOptions the callback is not called but instead grpc validates that this is not set when creating the ServerCredentials.

items.title: I'm trying to connect to grpc server with negotiation type TLS
items.body:
I'm looking for a similar kind of functionality in grpc python but I could not find it. Is it available in Python grpc. 

Here is similar code in Java
NettyChannelBuilder.forAddress(endpoint.getHost(), endpoint.getPort())
        .negotiationType(NegotiationType.TLS)
        .sslContext(GrpcSslContexts.forClient().trustManager(InsecureTrustManagerFactory.INSTANCE)
                .keyManager(new File(certPath), new File(keyPath))
                .build())
        .intercept(metadataInterceptor());

// ssl context with Negotiation Type TLS
NettyChannelBuilder.forAddress(endpoint.getHost(), endpoint.getPort())
        .negotiationType(NegotiationType.TLS)
        .sslContext(GrpcSslContexts.forClient().trustManager(InsecureTrustManagerFactory.INSTANCE).build())
        .intercept(metadataInterceptor());

items.title: (c++) gRPC client in Windows Service fails due to an absl::strcat call (for release build only)
items.body:
### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?
VCPKG: grpc:x86-windows 1.29.1 (c++)

### What operating system (Linux, Windows,...) and version?
Windows 10

### What runtime / compiler are you using (e.g. python version or version of gcc)
MSVC v142

### What did you do?
I have been implementing a simple Windows Service (https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/499465/Simple-Windows-Service-in-Cplusplus). I put a gRPC client inside the Event method that is making a hello to a server I have setup. When I run the event method directly (not as a windows service) the hello message goes through to the server perfectly fine (in debug/release). However, when I run the Event method as part of the ServiceWorkerThread the hello message fails in release (fine in debug). I've narrowed this down to the child_policy_handler.cc absl::StrCat call:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6597733/89909774-6f402c80-dbbd-11ea-913d-5ac75579015b.png)
when it works correctly it resolves in client_channel.cc AddTraceEvent as such:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6597733/89909989-aca4ba00-dbbd-11ea-9bac-27c3156a1654.png)
when it doesn't work correctly it resolves in client_channel.cc AddTraceEvent as such:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6597733/89910300-09a07000-dbbe-11ea-9141-64e9c29b2c0b.png)


### What did you expect to see?
I expected the gRPC hello message to function correctly and not have an issue resolving an absl call while in a windows service owned thread.

### What did you see instead?
An incorrect absl resolution resulting in an incorrect message size that created a heapinit error further down the call stack.

items.title: [ruby] grpc protoc plugin could generate broken request/response namespaces
items.body:
### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?

gRPC 1.30.2 on Ruby on Ubuntu bionic. Specifically the protoc plugin distributed as part of https://rubygems.org/gems/grpc-tools/versions/1.30.2

### What did you do?

Running the grpc protoc plugin on the [grafeas.v1 proto](https://github.com/googleapis/googleapis/tree/master/grafeas/v1) (as part of client library codegen).

The result looks like [this](https://github.com/googleapis/google-cloud-ruby/blob/0ada439dee22d319baf50c0e82174a4b8ce212db/grafeas-v1/lib/grafeas/v1/grafeas_services_pb.rb)

An excerpt with comments removed:

```ruby
require 'grpc'
require 'grafeas/v1/grafeas_pb'

module Grafeas
  module V1
    module Grafeas
      class Service

        include GRPC::GenericService

        self.marshal_class_method = :encode
        self.unmarshal_class_method = :decode
        self.service_name = 'grafeas.v1.Grafeas'

        rpc :GetOccurrence, Grafeas::V1::GetOccurrenceRequest, Grafeas::V1::Occurrence  # <-- error here

# and additional lines...
```

The indicated line results in an error:
```
/path/to/grafeas_services_pb.rb:48:in `<class:Service>': uninitialized constant Grafeas::V1::Grafeas::V1 (NameError)
Did you mean?  Grafeas::V1
```

This is happening because when Ruby does constant lookup on `Grafeas::V1::GetOccurrenceRequest`, it searches lexically up the namespace chain for `Grafeas` and instead of the toplevel `Grafeas` module, the first one it finds is actually the `Grafeas::V1::Grafeas` module.

The fix is to prefix the namespace with `::` which tells Ruby to search from the toplevel instead. That is, the above line should look like:

```ruby
        rpc :GetOccurrence, ::Grafeas::V1::GetOccurrenceRequest, ::Grafeas::V1::Occurrence
```

This is always safe to do whenever you are providing a "fully qualified" name, as you are above. (In fact, for generated code, it is good practice _always_ to do it, specifically to avoid this bug.)

Note that this is probably a regression from #23501 which, it seems, changed the behavior so that fully-qualified request and response class names are always generated.

grpc 1.30.1 generates:

```ruby
# Works because GetOccurrenceRequest is a "relative" class name
# i.e. it resolves correctly to Grafeas::V1::GetOccurrenceRequest
# and Grafeas::V1::Occurrence.
# (However, this version suffered from #23490 which was tangetially related)
rpc :GetOccurrence, GetOccurrenceRequest, Occurrence
```

grpc 1.30.2 generates:

```ruby
# Does not work. Resolves incorrectly to 
# Grafeas::V1::Grafeas::V1::GetOccurrenceRequest and
# Grafeas::V1::Grafeas::V1::Occurrence
rpc :GetOccurrence, Grafeas::V1::GetOccurrenceRequest, Grafeas::V1::Occurrence
```

What we want:

```ruby
# Explicitly do absolute rather than relative lookup. Resolves correctly to 
# Grafeas::V1::GetOccurrenceRequest and Grafeas::V1::Occurrence
rpc :GetOccurrence, ::Grafeas::V1::GetOccurrenceRequest, ::Grafeas::V1::Occurrence
```

/cc @stanley-cheung

items.title: Wrong return types in php code
items.body:
Hello. 

### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?
gRPC 1.30.2. 
PHP 7.3

### What operating system (Linux, Windows,...) and version?
Debian 10.5

### What did you do?
Today i've updated gprc-php-plugin and regenerated php code from my protofiles.After that PhpStorm and phpstan started to report type errors. After some research i've found this pr - #22671. It adds `return` phpdoc attribute to methods in generated client code. For example, let's generate `Math.proto`

Before this pr generated code for `Div` looked like this:
```php
/**
 * Div divides DivArgs.dividend by DivArgs.divisor and returns the quotient
 * and remainder.
 * @param \Math\DivArgs $argument input argument
 * @param array $metadata metadata
 * @param array $options call options
 */
public function Div(\Math\DivArgs $argument,
  $metadata = [], $options = []) {
    return $this->_simpleRequest('/math.Math/Div',
    $argument,
    ['\Math\DivReply', 'decode'],
    $metadata, $options);
}
```

After it looks like this:
```php
/**
 * Div divides DivArgs.dividend by DivArgs.divisor and returns the quotient
 * and remainder.
 * @param \Math\DivArgs $argument input argument
 * @param array $metadata metadata
 * @param array $options call options
 * @return \Math\DivReply
 */
public function Div(\Math\DivArgs $argument,
  $metadata = [], $options = []) {
    return $this->_simpleRequest('/math.Math/Div',
    $argument,
    ['\Math\DivReply', 'decode'],
    $metadata, $options);
}
```

Now, in code
```php
<?php

use Grpc\ChannelCredentials;

require_once 'vendor/autoload.php';

$client = new \Math\MathClient('localhost', [
    'credentials' => ChannelCredentials::createInsecure()
]);
$result = $client->Div(new \Math\DivArgs());

echo get_class($result) . PHP_EOL;

[$response, $status] = $result->wait();
```

IDE thinks that variable `$result` is of type `\Math\DivReply`:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1222013/89334691-582aa780-d6b0-11ea-89a9-eff8e83bfbde.png)


But it is not, it is of type `Grpc\UnaryCall`:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1222013/89334745-72fd1c00-d6b0-11ea-9f7b-5e20eb17e7f9.png)

And this is correct. But now, if we try to call `wait()` on result - there is ide error:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1222013/89334997-d8510d00-d6b0-11ea-9556-20ec8aa19cd5.png)

### What did you expect to see?
I think #22671 should be reverted or further improved. One way to improve is to replace 
```php
 * @return \Math\DivReply
```
with
```php
 * @return \Grpc\UnaryCall
```
or, to preserve result type, with additional comment:
```php
 * @return \Grpc\UnaryCall call with response type \Math\DivReply
```

I can provide PR if needed. Thanks.

items.title: Do we need this local object grpc_core::ExecCtx exec_ctx; in src/core/ext/transport/chttp2/server/insecure/server_chttp2.cc
items.body:
<!--
PLEASE DO NOT POST A QUESTION HERE.
This form is for bug reports and feature requests ONLY!

For general questions and troubleshooting, please ask/look for answers at StackOverflow, with "grpc" tag: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/grpc

For questions that specifically need to be answered by gRPC team members, please ask/look for answers at grpc.io mailing list: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/grpc-io

Issues specific to *grpc-java*, *grpc-go*, *grpc-node*, *grpc-dart*, *grpc-web* should be created in the repository they belong to (e.g. https://github.com/grpc/grpc-LANGUAGE/issues/new)
-->

I am working on QNX ARM platform. I am able to compile and generate the binaries successfully.
When I try to use these binaries to run the gRPC server, I am getting a coredump as below:
```
#0  0x0000000f8969ffe4 in grpc_combiner_continue_exec_ctx () at /local/mnt/workspace/temp/grpc_for_qnx/src/core/lib/iomgr/combiner.cc:184
#1  0x0000000f896482a8 in grpc_core::ExecCtx::Flush (this=this@entry=0x441c3a360) at /local/mnt/workspace/temp/grpc_for_qnx/src/core/lib/iomgr/exec_ctx.cc:156
#2  0x0000001cab04af80 in grpc_core::ExecCtx::~ExecCtx (this=0x441c3a360, __in_chrg=<optimized out>) at /local/mnt/workspace/temp/grpc_for_qnx/src/core/lib/iomgr/exec_ctx.h:124
#3  grpc_server_add_insecure_http2_port (server=<optimized out>, addr=0x7fd50f111 "0.0.0.0:62472")
    at /local/mnt/workspace/temp/grpc_for_qnx/src/core/ext/transport/chttp2/server/insecure/server_chttp2.cc:31
#4  0x0000001cab032658 in grpc_impl::Server::AddListeningPort (this=0x7fd535bd0, addr=..., creds=0x7fd4dd6d0)
    at /local/mnt/workspace/temp/grpc_for_qnx/src/cpp/server/server_cc.cc:1199
#5  0x0000001cab03082c in grpc_impl::ServerBuilder::BuildAndStart (this=this@entry=0x441c3a758) at /local/mnt/workspace/temp/grpc_for_qnx/src/cpp/server/server_builder.cc:411
#6  0x0000001cab026874 in qaic::QMonitorTaskStarter::startGRPCServerHelper (this=0x441bb9950, config=..., readyStatus=..., asyncTestSupport=false)
    at /local/mnt/workspace/qnx/runtime/lib/qmonitor/src/QMonitorTaskStarter.cpp:89
#7  0x0000001cab02a9b8 in std::__1::__invoke<void (qaic::QMonitorTaskStarter::*)(qaic::QMonitorGRPCTaskConfig const&, std::__1::promise<QStatus>, bool), qaic::QMonitorTaskStarter*, qaic::QMonitorGRPCTaskConfig, std::__1::promise<QStatus>, bool, void>(void (qaic::QMonitorTaskStarter::*&&)(qaic::QMonitorGRPCTaskConfig const&, std::__1::promise<QStatus>, bool), qaic::QMonitorTaskStarter*&&, qaic::QMonitorGRPCTaskConfig&&, std::__1::promise<QStatus>&&, bool&&) (__a0=<optimized out>, __f=<optimized out>)
    at /local/mnt/workspace/QNX_TARGET/qnx7/usr/include/c++/v1/__functional_base:382
#8  std::__1::__thread_execute<void (qaic::QMonitorTaskStarter::*)(qaic::QMonitorGRPCTaskConfig const&, std::__1::promise<QStatus>, bool), qaic::QMonitorTaskStarter*, qaic::QMonitorGRPCTaskConfig, std::__1::promise<QStatus>, bool, 1ul, 2ul, 3ul, 4ul> (__t=...)
    at /local/mnt/workspace/QNX_TARGET/qnx7/usr/include/c++/v1/thread:337
#9  std::__1::__thread_proxy<std::__1::tuple<void (qaic::QMonitorTaskStarter::*)(qaic::QMonitorGRPCTaskConfig const&, std::__1::promise<QStatus>, bool), qaic::QMonitorTaskStarter*, qaic::QMonitorGRPCTaskConfig, std::__1::promise<QStatus>, bool> > (__vp=0x7fd50f490)
    at /local/mnt/workspace/QNX_TARGET/qnx7/usr/include/c++/v1/thread:347
#10 0x0000000f8900b4e0 in pthread_attr_setdetachstate ()
   from /local/mnt/workspace/QNX_TARGET/qnx7/aarch64le/usr/lib/ldqnx-64.so.2
Backtrace stopped: previous frame identical to this frame (corrupt stack?) 
```

After investigation I root caused the issue. 
In file **src/core/ext/transport/chttp2/server/insecure/server_chttp2.cc** one local unused object is created **grpc_core::ExecCtx exec_ctx**.
When destructor of this object is called, we are getting a crash. Even this object is not been used in this function.
My suggesting to remove this line. Let me know if my suggestion is correct, because I am new to gRPC code.

items.title: grpc-python: calling init_grpc_aio twice results in all grpc calls to hang
items.body:
<!--
PLEASE DO NOT POST A QUESTION HERE.
This form is for bug reports and feature requests ONLY!

For general questions and troubleshooting, please ask/look for answers at StackOverflow, with "grpc" tag: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/grpc

For questions that specifically need to be answered by gRPC team members, please ask/look for answers at grpc.io mailing list: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/grpc-io

Issues specific to *grpc-java*, *grpc-go*, *grpc-node*, *grpc-dart*, *grpc-web* should be created in the repository they belong to (e.g. https://github.com/grpc/grpc-LANGUAGE/issues/new)
-->

### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?
```
grpcio==1.30.0
```

### What operating system (Linux, Windows,...) and version?
Linux

### What runtime / compiler are you using (e.g. python version or version of gcc)
python 3.8

### What did you do?
Please provide either 1) A unit test for reproducing the bug or 2) Specific steps for us to follow to reproduce the bug. If there’s not enough information to debug the problem, gRPC team may close the issue at their discretion. You’re welcome to re-open the issue once you have a reproduction.

```
import grpc.experimental.aio as grpcaio

grpcaio.init_grpc_aio()
grpcaio.init_grpc_aio()
await grpcaio.insecure_channel(address)
# never reached
```

### What did you expect to see?
Working

### What did you see instead?
Hang

### Anything else we should know about your project / environment?
I would say it is not be best practices to call init multiple times but I would expect it to not break - or at least be documented that it is not allowed to be called multiple times. The use case where I came across this was inside unit tests.

items.body:

-->

### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?

Python==3.8
grpcio==1.30.0
grpcio-tools==1.30.0
protobuf==3.12.4

### What operating system (Linux, Windows,...) and version?

Docker Image: 
```
tiangolo/uvicorn-gunicorn:python3.8
```

Kubernetes Version: 
1.16

Vendor:
Azure 

### What did you do?
Please provide either 1) A unit test for reproducing the bug or 2) Specific steps for us to follow to reproduce the bug. If there’s not enough information to debug the problem, gRPC team may close the issue at their discretion. You’re welcome to re-open the issue once you have a reproduction.

DNS resolution does not work when we pass the internal Kubernetes version

```
client = dex_api.DexStub(grpc.insecure_channel("dex-grpc.auth.svc.cluster.local:5557"))
```

It only works if you explicitly pass the ClusterIP for that service

```
client = dex_api.DexStub(grpc.insecure_channel("10.0.105.63:5557"))
```

### What did you expect to see?

DNS resolution should work with internal Kubernetes services.

### What did you see instead?

```

```

items.title: [ruby] module path names seems to be broken in >= v1.30.2
items.body:
### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?
grpc_tools_ruby_protoc 1.30.2

### What operating system (Linux, Windows,...) and version?
macOS 10.15.5
(Saw a similar issue in docker circleci/golang:1.13 image)

### What runtime / compiler are you using (e.g. python version or version of gcc)
Ruby 2.7.1 (also tried in 2.6.6)

### What did you do?
For v1.30.2 and newer, with the following `tmp.proto` file.
```
syntax = "proto3";

package task_planner;

service TaskPlanner {
  rpc Health(HealthRequest) returns (Status);
}

// Requests/Response
message Status {
  string msg = 1;
}

message HealthRequest {}
```

I ran `grpc_tools_ruby_protoc -I . --ruby_out=tmp1 --grpc_out=tmp1 tmp.proto`

This generates -
Filename: `tmp_pb.rb`
```
# Generated by the protocol buffer compiler.  DO NOT EDIT!
# source: tmp.proto

require 'google/protobuf'

Google::Protobuf::DescriptorPool.generated_pool.build do
  add_file("tmp.proto", :syntax => :proto3) do
    add_message "task_planner.Status" do
      optional :msg, :string, 1
    end
    add_message "task_planner.HealthRequest" do
    end
  end
end

module TaskPlanner
  Status = ::Google::Protobuf::DescriptorPool.generated_pool.lookup("task_planner.Status").msgclass
  HealthRequest = ::Google::Protobuf::DescriptorPool.generated_pool.lookup("task_planner.HealthRequest").msgclass
end
```

and 
Filename: `tmp_services_pb.rb`
```
# Generated by the protocol buffer compiler.  DO NOT EDIT!
# Source: tmp.proto for package 'task_planner'

require 'grpc'
require 'tmp_pb'

module TaskPlanner
  module TaskPlanner
    class Service

      include GRPC::GenericService

      self.marshal_class_method = :encode
      self.unmarshal_class_method = :decode
      self.service_name = 'task_planner.TaskPlanner'

      rpc :Health, TaskPlanner::HealthRequest, TaskPlanner::Status
    end

    Stub = Service.rpc_stub_class
  end
end
```

I then tried to load the generated service file in a shell.
In my local `tmp1` folder where the generated files are -
```
$ irb
irb(main):001:0> $LOAD_PATH << Dir.pwd
irb(main):002:0> require 'tmp_services_pb'
```


### What did you expect to see?
File to be successfully loaded

### What did you see instead?
It generates `NameError (uninitialized constant TaskPlanner::TaskPlanner::HealthRequest)`, which makes sense because the service file is not using absolute paths like `::TaskPlanner::HealthRequest`, hence it end up looking in the parent module.

Full trace
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
       10: from /Users/rahulagrawal/.rbenv/versions/2.6.6/bin/irb:23:in `<main>'
        9: from /Users/rahulagrawal/.rbenv/versions/2.6.6/bin/irb:23:in `load'
        8: from /Users/rahulagrawal/.rbenv/versions/2.6.6/lib/ruby/gems/2.6.0/gems/irb-1.0.0/exe/irb:11:in `<top (required)>'
        7: from (irb):2
        6: from /Users/rahulagrawal/.rbenv/versions/2.6.6/lib/ruby/2.6.0/rubygems/core_ext/kernel_require.rb:54:in `require'
        5: from /Users/rahulagrawal/.rbenv/versions/2.6.6/lib/ruby/2.6.0/rubygems/core_ext/kernel_require.rb:54:in `require'
        4: from /Users/rahulagrawal/Code/protobuf_definitions/tmp1/tmp_services_pb.rb:7:in `<top (required)>'
        3: from /Users/rahulagrawal/Code/protobuf_definitions/tmp1/tmp_services_pb.rb:8:in `<module:TaskPlanner>'
        2: from /Users/rahulagrawal/Code/protobuf_definitions/tmp1/tmp_services_pb.rb:9:in `<module:TaskPlanner>'
        1: from /Users/rahulagrawal/Code/protobuf_definitions/tmp1/tmp_services_pb.rb:17:in `<class:Service>'
NameError (uninitialized constant TaskPlanner::TaskPlanner::HealthRequest)
```

### Anything else we should know about your project / environment?
If I ran the same `grpc_tools_ruby_protoc` command with grpc-tools v1.30.1
I get the follow service file, which uses relative module name and loads fine.
```
# Generated by the protocol buffer compiler.  DO NOT EDIT!

require 'grpc'
require 'tmp_pb'

      self.marshal_class_method = :encode
      self.unmarshal_class_method = :decode
      self.service_name = 'task_planner.TaskPlanner'

      rpc :Health, HealthRequest, Status
    end

    Stub = Service.rpc_stub_class
  end
end
```

In shell sames steps
```
irb(main):001:0> $LOAD_PATH << Dir.pwd
irb(main):002:0> require 'tmp_services_pb'
=> true
```

items.title: Missing gRPCTargets.cmake file for hello world grpc with C++.
items.body:
@jtattermusch

CMake Error at /root/.local/lib/cmake/grpc/gRPCConfig.cmake:14 (include):
  include could not find load file:

    /root/.local/lib/cmake/grpc/gRPCTargets.cmake
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  CMakeLists.txt:116 (find_package)

Though I have refered #13841 and https://stackoverflow.com/questions/57413975/cmake-with-grpc-cannot-find-grpctargets-cmake, Still facing ame issue. 

I cross checked this command as well : 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6712693/88715041-4cccfe80-d13b-11ea-9119-c31b35486367.png)

This is the screenshot of my grpc/test/distrib/cpp/run_distrib_test_cmake.sh file. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6712693/88717461-383e3580-d13e-11ea-8b3b-4e7e8ce133a8.png)

One of the comment i read where it was mentioned that -
To fix this issue, you should carefully look at the output when invoking cmake. For every gRPC_*_PROVIDER that is reported as "module", you should force it to "package" with -DgRPC_CARES_PROVIDER=package (make sure to install the package as well, then!)

Do we have to update this at every places or only in grpc/test/distrib/cpp/run_distrib_test_cmake.sh file? Also Can we have once example how exactly we have to update that? 

Thanks in advance!!!

items.title: google/cloud-firestore v1.11.0 requires ext-grpc * -> the requested PHP extension grpc is missing from your system.

```
metadata=[

        ]
```
but it doesn't work.

### Describe the solution you'd like
add an API for Python to set User-Agent header, or make user-agent header in metadata working.

Haven't looked into the code.

### Additional context
my code here

items.title: update docs to not use (or clarify) google-specific term: "lameduck"
items.body:
RE: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/doc/PROTOCOL-HTTP2.md

As a small improvement, could the docs be updated to clarify what is meant here? 

HTTP2 Code | GRPC Code
-- | --
NO_ERROR(0) | INTERNAL - An explicit GRPC status of OK should have been sent but this might be used to aggressively lameduck in some scenarios.

Questions that arise:

1) What does "lameduck" mean? This seems a creative reuse of a political term that could perhaps be made more clear.

2) Similarly... what does "aggressively lameduck" mean? Perhaps a reference to the current US president after Nov. 3rd?

3) "....in some scenarios." what scenarios?

I'm trying to understand this error code as I'm seeing the following error in logs (coming from grpc-js used by google-gax):

```
Error: 13 INTERNAL: Received RST_STREAM with code 0"  
```

I was trying to use python grpc on the server with asyncio implementation. Even the simplest examples from unit tests fail just after I create the server instance object.

items.title: When I use localhost connect, if I use the IP it doesn't connect
“Peer name localhost is not in peer certificate” error
Conditional blocking shutdown
items.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

Currently `grpc_shutdown` always spawns a dedicated detached thread ([code](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/79c129472060b4142be97aba62c37d19cc79d5a8/src/core/lib/surface/init.cc#L221)) for executing the actual clean-up process. This is deliberately designed to prevent a self-join problem which can happen when `grpc_shutdown` is called from an executor thread. (Introduced by #17308, internal b/65754677 & b/119180212)

This behavior makes a subtle side-effect, a clean-up thread which outlives main thread. if the environment doesn't support this case, it could show an undefined behavior. Environments that we observed this problem; i) Visual C++ debug build which uses a debug-mode heap. (#22479) and ii) MSAN with Abseil Lock which uses a global variable (#21606)

This is mostly benign but it needs to be fixed to make unit tests using gRPC stable. Unit tests using gRPC under those environment tend to be flaky because of a detached clean-up thread.

### Describe the solution you'd like

gRPC team doesn't want to introduce a new API only for this. We agreed that making shutdown work differently depending on whether it's called from the an executor thread or not. If it's free from an executor thread, it can freely work in a blocking manner, which solves this problem. Otherwise, it has to spawn the thread and it will join it later.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

An easiest solution would be having a `grpc_shutdown_blocking` like api in gRPC C++ but it isn't ideal since users need to do extra step to use gRPC properly.

items.title: Support building without c-ares in CMake
items.body:
### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?
1.30.2 - C++

### What operating system (Linux, Windows,...) and version?
Ubuntu 16.04, 18.04, Windows 10, macOS (Mojave, Catalina)

### What runtime / compiler are you using (e.g. python version or version of gcc)
GCC5, GCC7, VS2017, VS2019, Apple LLVM version 10.0.1 (clang-1001.0.46.4), Apple clang version 11.0.3 (clang-1103.0.32.62)

### What did you do?
Attempt to build without the c-ares library using CMake.

### What did you expect to see?
I expected to be able to deactivate the use of c-ares and use the native DNS resolver instead (src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/native/dns_resolver.cc)
I expected failure to find the c-ares library would result in a `-DGRPC_ARES=0` definition.

### What did you see instead?
> src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_ev_driver.cc:23:10: fatal error: ares.h: No such file or directory

### Anything else we should know about your project / environment?
This can be solved by adding an `else` case at the end of the `cmake/cares.cmake` file:

```
# ...
else()
  add_definitions(-DGRPC_ARES=0)
endif()
```
After doing this gRPC for C++ and Python (the languages that we use) build fine.

I can prepare a PR doing this if you are interested.

items.title: call reports empty response payload even if the call ended with an OK status
items.body:
Internal bug tracking - b/160009494 (found by @sheenaqotj)

The issue is that if the call deadline fires, it is possible for the transport to drop the incoming messages even if it has received an OK status. This happens in the case that the transport has received the status, closed reads and writes, but it hasn't yet invoked the callback for receiving trailing metadata.

A more detailed explanation of the steps to reach to this point - 
1) Client starts a call with a deadline.
2) The transport receives the OK status and is both read and write closed.
3) The recv_trailing_metadata callback has not been called. (One possible reason for the callback not having been called yet is that there is still pending data to be reported)
4) The deadline fires.
5) gRPC currently cancels the stream but does not fake the status since the status has already been received and the stream is both read and write closed.

To fix this, we could either -
1) Not cancel the stream if it is both read and write closed already.
2) Fake the status and the trailing metadata effectively overwriting the existing trailing metadata, so that if the messages are dropped due to cancellation, we also update the status.

I think 1) is the right fix to this

items.title: Epollex's MAX_EPOLL_EVENTS_HANDLED_EACH_POLL_CALL can leave stranded notifications
items.body: This issue was noticed in an integration test (b/158778652), but `//test/core/iomgr:stranded_event_test` in PR https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/23535 is a minimal repro of it. To reproduce, pull down https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/23535, remove the changes to `src/core/lib/iomgr/ev_epollex_linux.cc`, then: ``` make stranded_event_test -j8 i=0; while [[ $? == 0 ]]; do ((i++)) || true; echo $i && bins/opt/stranded_event_test; done; ``` (this assumes that the epollex poller will be used) A failure should pop up pretty quickly, e.g. like this one: ``` $ i=0; while [[ $? == 0 ]]; do ((i++)) || true; echo $i && bins/opt/stranded_event_test; done; 1 D0717 12:44:35.871915736 988379 test_config.cc:386] test slowdown factor: sanitizer=1, fixture=1, poller=1, total=1 [==========] Running 1 test from 1 test suite. [----------] Global test environment set-up. [----------] 1 test from Pollers [ RUN ] Pollers.TestReadabilityNotificationsDontGetStrandedOnOneCq E0717 12:44:51.541157255 988562 cq_verifier.cc:214] no event received, but expected:0x7f972400f3e0 GRPC_OP_COMPLETE success=1 test/core/iomgr/stranded_event_test.cc:148 E0717 12:44:51.541163236 988559 cq_verifier.cc:214] no event received, but expected:0x7f9718016da0 GRPC_OP_COMPLETE success=1 test/core/iomgr/stranded_event_test.cc:148 ******************************* Caught signal SIGABRT Aborted ``` To exaggerate the issue and get it to reproduce ~100%, tune down [MAX_EPOLL_EVENTS_HANDLED_EACH_CALL](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/97fdeb873a144ea7eca653eca9d81a5a3681e947/src/core/lib/iomgr/ev_epollex_linux.cc#L73) to e.g. 4, 2, or 1. To fix it completely, tune `MAX_EPOLL_EVENTS_HANDLED_EACH_CALL` up to 100, to be the same as [MAX_EPOLL_EVENTS](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/47c6c826f7f56207918720cb6cf046a3497a8328/src/core/lib/iomgr/ev_epollex_linux.cc#L69). The benchmark that highlighted this issue, which is similar to the repro, hits this issue frequently due to the following setup: a) Application has multiple RPCs, where each RPC has its own channel, its own CQ, and also its own connection to a backend b) The epoll sets of all CQ's get merged together. - In the benchmark, this happened to be the case because the client channels were using ALTS credentials, and ALTS credentials create a channel to the same metadata server address with the same channel args, so the subchannel to the metadata server can be shared (when this happens, the ALTS handshake's pollset set will get added to the shared subchannel's pollset set, eventually joining everyone's pollsets together). - The repro gets this to happen by using round_robin load balancing, and using a common shared "dummy" address among the address list, so when channels share that subchannel they also wind up joining their pollset sets together. c) Work on RPC is done in "rounds". So RPCs 1-N all send messages and receive a responses concurrently. After all work is done, they all do another ping pong, and so on. What appears to happen when the failure is hit, one of the RPCs will hit a timeout while waiting for a message to be received. Looking at a packet trace, we can see that data actually arrives on its TCP connection, but its CQ/pollset never gets a notification. With some logging, we can see that one of the CQ's in the process did actually get an epoll notification for the TCP connection that the timed out RPC was interested in, but it never did anything about that event because it exitted `pollset_work` and stopped polling before processing all epoll events. This happened because one of the file descriptors earlier in the event list triggered a CQ "receive message op" completion, which allowed that RPC to stop polling its CQ, leaving epoll events further down the event list unprocessed. Note that we can get lucky and other CQ's in the process might get those same epoll events, but because we're using EPOLLEXCLUSIVE, we don't have a guarantee that any more than one epoll fd will get an event. So if the timing is right, we can leave "stranded" events which don't get processed in a timely manner.

items.body:
### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?

### What operating system (Linux, Windows,...) and version?
Windows 10 (64-Bit)

### What runtime / compiler are you using (e.g. python version or version of gcc)
.NET Core 3.1 / Visual Studio 2019

`await server.ShutdownAsync().ConfigureAwait(false);`

Server shutting down.

items.title: [Ruby] grpc_tools_ruby_protoc generates wrong namespace for fully-qualified rpc response type
items.body:
### What version of gRPC and what language are you using?

grpc_tools_ruby_protoc 1.30.1 (see https://rubygems.org/gems/grpc-tools/versions/1.30.1) on Ubuntu bionic

### What did you do?

Running the grpc protoc plugin on the google.cloud.oslogin.v1 proto (as part of client library codegen). The GetSshPublicKey and UpdateSshPublicKey RPCs generate an incorrect Ruby type for their response type.

Proto: https://github.com/googleapis/googleapis/blob/1b969c28a6579265e89cd35e6c2ecacc89970e2d/google/cloud/oslogin/v1/oslogin.proto#L72

Result: https://github.com/googleapis/google-cloud-ruby/pull/7036/files#diff-963ba7c73491dae821dd8275d003634e (you'll have to click View Diff to see it).

Here's a screen shot in case the PR gets closed: ![screen shot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8911/87488884-61b37900-c5f6-11ea-9348-a31b36e624c4.png)

Note that the generated type of the response is incorrect (part of the namespace is duplicated).

Some items of note that might be pertinent to this case:
* The response in the proto is fully-qualified.
* The proto has defined a custom Ruby namespace (i.e. a `ruby_package` proto option). The response type is also in a custom Ruby namespace.

Note that the "extra" namespace path that is being added corresponds to the "fully-qualified" segments of the response type, but does not conform to the custom Ruby namespace for this proto. (Look carefully at the case of the "L" in "OsLogin".)

**This appears to be a regression in grpc_tools 1.30.** (Previous generation runs using 1.28 did not exhibit this behavior.)

items.title: Python - grpc.ServicerContext..invocation_metadata() - subclasses return different value types
items.body:
Hello gRPC team!
I've stumbled across this bug in grpcio python:
the server-side context returns different types of value in method invocation_metadata().
in grpcio-testing: returns dict
in grpcio: return tuple of tuples

I need therefore to explicitly check return type in my code to avoid failing in either tests or normal run

items.title: Why multiprocess python grpc server do not work?
items.body:
I instantiate one grpc server per subprocess by multiprocess pool. When I use multiple clients to access the server, I found the following two problems：

- **all clients access same server subprocess**
- **client raise MaybeEncodingError**

The details of this problem see [Why multiprocess python grpc server do not work?](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/62798507/why-multiprocess-python-grpc-server-do-not-work)

items.title: How can we detect client sudden disconnection (network failure/ App crash) at the gRPC server?
items.body:
Server is written using Grpc.Core in C#
Client is written in python and C# both.
-Purpose is to cleanup user/client specific resources at the server in case of client disconnection.

items.title: Fix interceptor batch method FailHijackedRecvMessage for generic async APIs
items.body:
https://github.com/grpc/grpc/commit/edbae5d8e66fd72c8ac743dd54fa41319a5e251b#diff-64b4460fd28efb376a5cd7aafc925085R551 fixed interceptor batch method `FailHijackedRecvMessage` for `CallOpRecvMessage`, but not for `CallOpGenericRecvMessage`.

`CallOpGenericRecvMessage:: FinishOp()` still bails out early if the call is `hijacked_`, here: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/209de73b394e6ecea1715514770ef720ab69895b/include/grpcpp/impl/codegen/call_op_set.h#L551

...which means this condition will never be true: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/209de73b394e6ecea1715514770ef720ab69895b/include/grpcpp/impl/codegen/call_op_set.h#L561

cc @yashykt

items.title: C# ValueTask based service API to reduce allocations
items.body:
Hello,

I am working on a grpc service in dot.net. It is built with high throughput in mind. I have attempted to remove all allocations from requests, and managed to do that for the most part.

The final allocations i have are:
1.Task
2.TaskCompletionSource
3.The async machinery instance
4.The response proto message

I was thinking that maybe i can get rid of the first 3 by using the ValueTask API backed by IValueTaskSource. However this would require the grpc service to return ValueTask to properly avoid allocations.
Is there any initiatives to introduce ValueTask returning service methods? Perhaps i am not the first person to propose this.

As for the allocated proto message, i was thinking to reuse the instances as well, but for that i would require a callback to know that the request is complete. Is there a way to achieve such a notification, so that i can reuse the object for another request?
